name: NPR
text:
Listen to Billie Eilish's new song "My Future." Written and recorded in Los Angeles during lockdown, it's a dreamy ode to freedom.
https://t.co/YkmEUHEGA1

name: NPR
text:
A trillion dollars worth of American farmland will change hands in the coming years — as wealthy investors increasingly buy it up.

But their decisions, from hundreds of miles away, will have serious impacts on rural communities and the environment.
https://t.co/fX4wSd4AAi

name: NPR
text: Two members of the Philadelphia Phillies staff tested positive for the coronavirus following the team’s weekend series against the Miami Marlins, who paused their season due to a COVID-19 outbreak.  https://t.co/1yHT1OUgG5

name: NPR
text:
"He believed that in all of us, there exists the capacity for great courage, that in all of us there is a longing to do what's right."

Read Barack Obama's emotional eulogy for John Lewis:
https://t.co/znlMk6TbfR

name: NPR
text:
Voters in Missouri will soon decide whether to expand eligibility for the state's Medicaid program to provide insurance to more than 230,000 additional people.

If it passes, coverage for the newly eligible would begin in 2021.
https://t.co/U75LMCayZI

name: NPR
text:
As the coronavirus surges in Mexico, low earners make up the highest share of deaths — and lack the funds to stay afloat during the deepening recession.

Now, pressure is rising on the hesitant government to offer financial help.
https://t.co/kxVSPNOQBG

name: NPR
text:
Amazon’s sales skyrocketed amid the pandemic, hitting close to $89 billion — a 40% increase from last year.

The jump in sales coincides with an economic crisis that has left many retailers struggling to survive. 
https://t.co/hdi1RQDQc6

name: NPR
text:
California has been using inmates to fight fires since the 1940s. But this summer, many were sent home because of COVID-19.

And as the state enters peak fire season, its forces are down significantly.
https://t.co/PnR1fjzVNO

name: NPR
text:
President Trump claims that Republicans hate vote-by-mail. 

But a recent poll found that half of all Republicans nationwide support allowing all registered voters access to a mail ballot.
https://t.co/7gYhQoIRjA

name: NPR
text:
Across the country, at least 100 Catholic schools will close in the fall because of the COVID-19 economic crisis.

And low-income families and students of color will be hit especially hard.
https://t.co/MYcXfAZ5Sc

name: NPR
text:
Two new studies involving monkeys suggest COVID-19 vaccine candidates can provide disease protection after a single injection — but it will take large-scale human trials to know for sure if they work.
https://t.co/I4KOFOSlw1

name: NPR
text:
A series of unusual decisions led to a private tech company winning a federal contract to gather key COVID-19 data instead of the CDC, NPR found.

The company's CEO is a longtime Republican donor with ties to Trump Organization financiers.
https://t.co/2D679CsWYG

name: NPR
text:
For the first time, scientists have modified the genes of a squid.

The success shows that cephalopods can finally be studied using the same genetic tools that let scientists explore the biology of more familiar lab animals — like mice and fruit flies.
https://t.co/PlEn3TyQVk

name: NPR
text:
"You Can't Take It with You — but evidently you can perform it forever."

From "Our Town" to "The Crucible," take a look at the most popular high school plays and musicals since the 1930s.
https://t.co/R5X7Ju92ks

name: NPR
text:
NEW: The Census Bureau is cutting short critical door-knocking efforts for the 2020 census amid growing concerns among Democrats in Congress that the White House is pressuring the bureau to wrap up counting soon for political gain, NPR has learned.
https://t.co/HU31j2DyAe

name: NPR
text:
This month marks the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act, considered the most important civil rights law since the 1960s.

On @throughlineNPR, we look back at how it came to be — and what the disability community is still fighting for.
https://t.co/PO0klqKz8Z

name: NPR
text:
A delay in counting mail ballots should be seen as a sign that officials are safeguarding against the sort of fraud Trump says he is worried about, says Pennsylvania's secretary of state.
https://t.co/bOoIBPQwYr

name: NPR
text:
Author Robert P. Jones examines the legacy of white supremacy among Southern Baptists and other denominations.

On social justice, he says, "White Christians have been largely silent ... and have hardly begun these conversations."
https://t.co/QjUkJQ9DKJ

name: NPR
text:
Terrorism analysts warn that far-right and anti-government agitators are either attacking protesters or trying to glom onto their cause to push their own agendas.

And with street clashes already happening, they fear the worst is yet to come.
https://t.co/HjHyVZj7nO

name: NPR
text:
HBCUs have an extra factor to consider as they decide if schools will reopen in the fall:

Black people are dying from the coronavirus at two and a half times the rate of white people. 
https://t.co/5wOWMI9VOC

name: NPR
text:
Inspired by her family, a high school senior has created a tool that predicts crop harvests to help reduce food insecurity.

"I have watched my younger siblings struggle with the lifelong effects of malnutrition," she says.
https://t.co/zXZODXCN0o

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. GDP shrank by a record 32.9% in the second quarter. But the way GDP is reported can skew impressions of the economy.

Here’s what that number really means, and how much a gauge of the future it represents. https://t.co/MV6g5L8a5T

name: NPR
text:
"Will I come out of here? Racing thoughts. A close friend has already died from COVID-19. I’m not sure I’ll ever see my husband again."

Journalist Anna King felt fine on the morning of June 3. Then a fever came — 104 degrees. (@KUOW) https://t.co/IV2LKf9nLy

name: NPR
text:
It can be hard to forgive. But forgiving someone actually has benefits for your mental health. The practice of radical forgiveness can help you process hurt and anger — and, ultimately, find peace.

Here are some tips to get started. (@nprlifekit)
https://t.co/XqA9HFAxvo

name: NPR
text:
Two novels to add to your summer reading list:

📕 “The Aunt Who Wouldn't Die” centers on an Indian family haunted by a jealous ghost.

📘 “Blacktop Wasteland” is a noir thriller — with muscle cars.
https://t.co/rpOtUh6HRj

name: NPR
text:
"Magic: The Gathering" is a trading card game that's been around for almost three decades — with millions of players worldwide .

But the pandemic has presented additional financial and health hurdles for players to now clear.
https://t.co/NwoIJzxy6G

name: NPR
text:
Oregon has a long history of racism, dating back to its statehood in 1859, when the constitution barred Black people from living there. 

But recent protests are part of another long history of residents combating that lingering racism.
https://t.co/OSn85gDK4N

name: NPR
text:
Do you believe that people can fundamentally change, or do you think we just are who we are? If you chose the former, you've got something in common with @perfumegenius’ Mike Hadreas.

He talks change, new album and dance project. 👇
https://t.co/xnHL0pMhqb

name: NPR
text:
Jazz drummer @MakayaMcCraven has a unique style where he makes improvised live recordings, then builds on them in the studio. 

 “It's kind of like a collage of what happened live in the moment in that space,” he says.
https://t.co/b34fVF5aV3

name: NPR
text:
“Unspeakable Acts” works as both a superb collection of true crime writing and a text that looks at our collective obsession with horrific murders, con men and serial killers in a historical and cultural context.
https://t.co/pAkhZbMplg

name: NPR
text:
Ohio's House replaced Larry Householder as its speaker Thursday, hours after voting unanimously to remove him.

The same day, a federal grand jury indicted Householder with conspiracy to commit racketeering, a charge punishable by up to 20 years in prison.
https://t.co/dg07E5sVcu

name: NPR
text:
Earlier this month, the Trump administration abruptly required hospitals to stop reporting COVID-19 data to the CDC—and to use a new online system instead.

But that new system has proven to be rife with errors and inconsistent updates, data analysts say.
https://t.co/c6sg0yOPBO

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge has unsealed hundreds of pages of documents related to a now-settled defamation suit brought against Ghislaine Maxwell.

It includes previously unseen emails between Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein—and a deposition given by one of his accusers.
https://t.co/ngjNMvhww1

name: NPR
text:
A new report from the centrist Democratic group Third Way finds that Democrats are on track to win the suburbs in five key states they lost in the 2016 election.
https://t.co/XrtIeZU2EZ

name: NPR
text:
Across the country, school nurses face an unprecedented task: caring for students and staff during a pandemic.

But one poll found that 40% of school nurses said they weren't involved in conversations about pandemic planning with their school teams.
https://t.co/IFmZ50yM7n

name: NPR
text:
Three executive producers on "The Ellen DeGeneres Show" have been accused of sexual misconduct, amid a new wave of workplace misconduct complains made by 36 former staffers.
https://t.co/vZnSHhVTQP

name: NPR
text:
In two blistering decisions, a federal judge has put a temporary freeze on restrictive Trump administration policies that attempt to widen the criteria for what makes an immigrant a "public charge."
https://t.co/rSRH7B6sun

name: NPR
text:
The House has unanimously passed a resolution to reprimand GOP Rep. David Schweikert for breaking congressional and campaign finance rules. 

He admitted to 11 ethics violations and agreed to pay a $50,000 fine.
https://t.co/bVuJQRPnl5

name: NPR
text:
The federal government has reached a deal worth up to $2.1 billion with drugmakers Sanofi and GlaxoSmithKline for another coronavirus vaccine candidate.
https://t.co/PheS9gKFgR

name: NPR
text:
Florida has set a new record for the number of COVID-19 deaths for the fourth day in a row.

"What we're seeing now is the result of the push to open the state," a public health expert says.
https://t.co/L6aaFA85nR

name: NPR
text:
The NIH is giving $248.7 million to seven companies developing new tech for COVID testing.

One employs a revolutionary gene-editing tool. Another uses a hand-held device that produces results within 30 minutes.
https://t.co/Vlsz70LJHt

name: NPR
text:
Of the countries reporting the most coronavirus cases, 6 out of 7 are middle-income nations. (The other is the U.S.)

They're major emerging market economies, regional political powers — and they're especially vulnerable to the impact of the crisis.
https://t.co/31RrlnbUwK

name: NPR
text:
Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam is delaying the region's legislative elections by a year — citing a resurgence in coronavirus cases.

Critics have decried it as the latest move to erode Hong Kong's autonomy.
https://t.co/lNyYfb6Bmf

name: NPR
text:
Citing promising animal and human trials, Dr. Anthony Fauci told lawmakers a coronavirus vaccine could be ready for distribution by the end of the year, and distributed to Americans in 2021. 
https://t.co/ZmFONCQhMs

name: NPR
text:
After bringing the number of local coronavirus cases down to zero, Hong Kong is seeing its biggest surge since the outbreak began  — reporting more than 100 new cases a day.
https://t.co/hxO2ElWTDM

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRItsBeenAMin: ✨ NEW EPISODE ✨

🏃🏽‍♀️ Should I wear a mask when I run? 
📱 How dirty is my phone? 
🐶 Can I say hello to dogs? 

You had questions about coronavirus, @samsanders and @maddie_sofia have answers.

Plus, @hafsabadsha on #IndianMatchmaking.

LISTEN NOW 🔊 https://t.co/6IwJWNQJY1

name: NPR
text: Gov. Ron DeSantis has declared a state of emergency for coastal counties in Florida ahead of Hurricane Isaias, which is expected to bring a dangerous storm surge, flooding and high winds. https://t.co/VeY6Al2Nuy

name: NPR
text: Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok, the hugely popular Chinese-owned app, just as the Trump administration considers taking action against the app — including banning it. https://t.co/vOf5pOfkYw

name: NPR
text:
The coronavirus is surging in Syria and hospitals are overwhelmed — lacking medicine, tests and equipment.

Authorities are using an intimidation campaign to suppress information about the outbreak, a medical worker says.
https://t.co/ogxC9Ivv8e

name: NPR
text:
NEW: James Murdoch has resigned from the board of News Corp, the publishing arm of his family's media empire, citing "disagreements over certain editorial content" and "other strategic decisions."
https://t.co/QjFcy7FdqN
